occupation: Director of the Center for Cyber Security and Forensics Education & Asst Prof of Info Tech and Mgmt at Illinois Institute of Technology
headline: Cybersecurity Center Director  at Illinois Tech | Fulbright Scholar 5x | 2021 Researcher to Know | 40 under 40 in Cybersecurity 2022
summary: Dr. Maurice Dawson is an Assistant Professor of Information Technology and Management within the College of Computing at Illinois Institute of Technology.   Additionally, he serves as Director and Distinguished Member of the Center for Cyber Security and Forensics Education (C2SAFE). Before joining academia, he was an engineering manager for unmanned air systems and senior program manager for rotary-wing aircraft.  Dawson completed a postdoctoral study in Systems and Information Technology (IT) at University Fernando Pessoa. He has a Doctor of Computer Science from Colorado Technical University and a Doctor of Philosophy in Cyber Security from the Intelligent Systems Research Centre at London Metropolitan University.  Dawson has recently received his fourth Fulbright Scholar Grant to teach and conduct research at the Botswana International University of Science and Technology. Additionally, he is the co-editor of Developing Next-Generation Countermeasures for Homeland Security Threat Prevention and New Threats and Countermeasures in Digital Crime and Cyber Terrorism, published by IGI Global in 2017, and 2015 respectively. The United States (US) Department of Defense (DoD) 8140 recognized him for the roles of Information Assurance Manager (IAM) Level II & III, Cyber Security Service Provider (CSSP) Manager, and Information Assurance Systems Architect and Engineer (IASAE) I & II. His research areas are cyber operations, software assurance, cyber strategy, and cyber-terrorism.

Additionally, serving as Director of the National Center for Academic Excellence in Cyber Security Education and responsible for working with the faculty who are members of this center.

experiences.description: Servedas a Fulbright Scholar in the Department of Computer Science and Information Systems at Botswana International University of Science and Technology (BIUST).  The role was to teach an undergraduate course in Operating Systems Cyber Security while the primary task was to conduct research.  Worked on projects with the Botswana Defence Forces (BDF),  Botswana Power Corporation (BPC), South African Development Community (SADC), and others.

experiences.company: Institut Supérieur des Etudes Technologiques en Communications de Tunis
experiences.title: Visiting Researcher
Editor in Chief of the International Journal of Hyperconnectivity and the Internet of Things
experiences.description: The mission of the International Journal of Hyperconnectivity and the Internet of Things (IJHIoT) is to explore a range of related topics and generate research debates in relation to cyber security, hyperconnectivity, Internet of Things (IoT), Web of Things (WoT), and Internet of Everything (IoE). Targeting researchers, practitioners, academicians, government officials, military professionals and other industry professionals, IJHIoT provides a forum to discuss technical, human, societal, and policy issues in relation to hyperconnectivity, and IoT. Articles published in IJHIoT deal with a vast number of issues concerning usage, failure, success, policies, strategies, security concerns, the development, and integration of IoT applications in organizations in and across developed, emerging and developing nations.

experiences.title: Visiting Assistant Professor
experiences.description: Served as a Visiting Assistant Professor at the Technical University Munich researching cybersecurity and the Internet of Things (IoT).

experiences.title: Founder
experiences.description: Founder of the iHyperconnectivity Lab which is a research based group focused on hyperconnectivity, Internet of Things (IoT), and other emerging technologies.

experiences.title: Membership and Publicity Director
experiences.description: Serving on the MWAIS Executive Committee as the Membership & Publicity Director and the Newsletter Editor.

experiences.title: Assistant Professor of Information Systems
experiences.description: Served as an Assistant Professor of Information Systems – Cyber Security with the role of developing a Center of Excellence for Cyber Security. Additional role includes obtaining degree accreditation with Committee on National Security Standards (CNSS), and preparation to become a National Security Agency (NSA) & Department of Homeland Security (DHS) Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) which the university obtained April 2016. Developing innovative coursework such as software assurance and advanced cyber security concepts. Received a research fellowship through the American Policy & Leadership Foundation (ALPF) as a Senior Research Fellow, received the International Studies & Program (ISP) Fellowship, and awarded 3 Fulbright Scholar Specialist grants.  Currently an International Business (IB) Research Associate in the UMSL International Business Institute (IBI).

accomplishment_projects.title: Walden 2.1:  A Technological Society
accomplishment_projects.description:
Consensus of Prefrontal Cortex activity sought in Midterm Feedback by Richard Courchesne, submitted May 8, 2013:

It must be evident to society that part of innovation “Life Cycle” may offer great speeds and convenience, until something better comes along; but it also eliminates the need for human cell to perform physical exertion for pay.  As less and less human cells are needed to perform the tasks of iterations the physical work will go to non-complaining 24/7 worker-robotics.  According to Ray Kurzweil, the near future will indeed be a very different place.  Breakthroughs of disruptive innovation in bio-nanotechnology and artificial intelligences projects carbon nanoparticle-organic robots that can cluster into solid exoskeleton shapes of any desired object, that is capable of performing any function that serves the needs of humankind (Kurzweil, 2005).

Patterns are emerging that may suggest a direct correlation between industrial occupational downsizing, a term referring to an event when human cell jobs becomes replaced by automation; and its relationship to Kurzweil’s “Life Cycle of Innovation” to an asymptotic discreet value.  An economic paradigm shift is on the horizon as the value of work redefines (Castellani & Hafferty, 2009; Kurzweil, 2005; Joyner et al., 2013).

accomplishment_projects.title: New Threats and Countermeasures in Digital Crime and Cyber Terrorism
accomplishment_projects.description:
Technological advances, although beneficial and progressive, can lead to vulnerabilities in system networks and security. While researchers attempt to find solutions, negative uses of technology continue to create new security threats to users.

New Threats and Countermeasures in Digital Crime and Cyber Terrorism brings together research-based chapters and case studies on security techniques and current methods being used to identify and overcome technological vulnerabilities with an emphasis on security issues in mobile computing and online activities. This book is an essential reference source for researchers, university academics, computing professionals, and upper-level students interested in the techniques, laws, and training initiatives currently being implemented and adapted for secure computing.

accomplishment_projects.title: Tech Linux Research Institute
accomplishment_projects.description: AAMU's only lab to facilitate penetration testing, cyber security, virtual learning, systems engineering, software development, and more with the use of open source software (OSS).

accomplishment_projects.title: Logistics & Supply Chain Management Virtual Machine
accomplishment_projects.description: This project was to develop a virtual machine (VM) for the logistics and supply chain management degree program at Alabama A&M University.  The VM contained all coursebooks, case studies, scholarly journals, and open source software (OSS) programs for the course.  This VM was developed for student and faculty use.  This program was developed as a summer research project with a forthcoming proceedings publication in the Proceedings of the 8th International Technology, Education and Development Conference in Valencia, Spain March 2014.

accomplishment_projects.title: Unmanned Air System (UAS) Project for PROJ660 Course
accomplishment_projects.description: This course introduced students to project cost estimation techniques. Students learned how to adjust cost estimates based on resource availability and project risk, and evaluate quality of cost estimates prepared by others.  Students learned the earned-value management technique.   Students use software package(s) to estimate costs.  The associated project was to build an Unmanned Air System (UAS), website, document, and capture all costs associated with weekly cost reports.  This course was designed to reflect a real defense project using principles of Earned Value Management (EVM) in aerospace setting.

recommendations:
Dr. Karl B. Ostler



I had the pleasure of studying under Dr. Dawson while attending a doctoral course in Computer Science (DCS) within the Institute for Advanced Studies (IAS) at Colorado Technical University. Although time was short, I found Dr. Dawson open to communicating and sharing his knowledge. This is where I found him to be a plethora of knowledge. He continues to impress me with both the breadth and depth of his knowledge as he participates in many different forums and as he continues to post and share various articles. Thanks for the connection, and keep up the great work Dr. Dawson.  -K

Adam Austin



Dr. Dawson, with his emphasis on continual self-improvement, has been an inspiration for my career.  He is a results-oriented leader who does not lose sight of the importance of maintaining good personal relationships as an integral part of producing successful products.  Since I have been at AAI, Dr. Dawson has overseen the three-fold growth of our IA department, all the while maintaining a 100% success rate for DIACAP accreditation of our products.

Donald H. Miller



Maurice is a consummate professional..he "gets it". He leads and collaborates with the highest level of integrity. Dependable and trustworthy, he has the mettle to succeed in any capacity.

Jason Brower



When I first met Maurice many years ago, he struck me as a very ambitious man with a positive attitude, willingness to achieve and desire to go above and beyond what was expected of him by both his co-workers and his customers.

Over the years and in what feels a very short period of time, Maurice has achieved goals that never surprise me as I was very aware of his capabilities, yet I often shake my head with a smile wondering what he will do next.  He is a talented co-worker, a respected friend and a colleague I would gladly work for or with again without question.

Kimberly Mendoza



Maurice was always very attentive to detail as they related to his program and what his duties were. He made it very easy to complete my job by keeping me informed of activities that he was involved in and was always a professional in every aspect of the word. In addition he was a pleasure to work with and I highly recommend him for any position that he may obtain.

Andrae Grey, MBA, ABD



As one of our Computer Information Systems professors, Prof. Dawson continues to do an excellent job in mentoring and motivating our student body at Strayer. His students find him to not only be personable but also professional and always willing to go the extra mile to ensure that they fully grasp the pertinent material.
 He has a full understanding of the course work required by the students and also the patience and temperament to convey that understand to all students, from the most advanced to the neolithic.

Cynthia Calongne



As a new addition to Maurice Dawson's research committee, my work with Mr. Dawson has been limited, yet has convinced me of his commitment to excellence. He has strong analytical skills and applies them as he explores a variety of alternatives for investigating his hypothesis.

Wayne Staats



Maurice has been committed to better himself, whether it be within a engineering or project management position.  Furthermore, he has used this design to help others better themselves to by developing training courses in the area of Information Assurance.  These courses, adopted company wide, clearly demonstrate Maurice's grasp of the IA field.

John Garcia



Maurice is an incredibly successful engineer, especially concerning project engineering. For someone so young, his natural abilities to manage are just maturing and his potential for more responsibility grows every day.
